title: Case Study 4
description:
• The study analyzes and models the Boston Housing Data using CART (Classification and Regression Trees) and Linear Regression.
  • The German Credit Data is examined to classify credit defaults using Decision Trees.
methodology:
Boston Housing Data:

  • Loaded the data from the MASS library.
  • Split the dataset into 90% training and 10% testing.
  • Built and visualized a regression tree model to predict the target median home value (medv).
  • Used the prp function to visualize the regression tree.
  • Calculated in-sample MSE (Mean Squared Error) of 17.2 and out-of-sample MSE of 27.4, indicating possible overfitting.
  • Created a linear regression model, excluding the indus and age variables.
  • The linear regression model had an in-sample MSE of 21.5 and out-of-sample MSE of 25.5, showing that CART might fit non-linear relationships better.

German Credit Data:

  • Loaded and preprocessed the German Credit dataset, converting categorical variables into factors.
  • Split the dataset into 80% training and 20% testing.
  • Built a classification tree predicting credit defaults.
  • Developed a second model applying a weighted cost matrix (false negatives cost 5x more than false positives).
  • Compared the models and evaluated misclassification costs.
  • Tested out-of-sample performance, showing possible improvements in handling misclassifications.

overview.story: -Examined real-world housing and credit data to build predictive models. -Compared different machine learning techniques to evaluate their effectiveness.
overview.collectedData: -Boston Housing dataset (various real estate features). -German Credit dataset (loan defaults and financial indicators).
overview.conclusions: -Boston Housing dataset (various real estate features). -German Credit dataset (loan defaults and financial indicators).

title: Test Case Study
description: "Analyzing consumer behavior in online shopping using machine learning models."
methodology: "Used Python (Pandas, NumPy) for data preprocessing, applied Logistic Regression and Decision Trees for classification, and evaluated models using F1-score."

overview.story: "With e-commerce growing rapidly, understanding customer behavior is critical. This case study explores various factors that influence purchase decisions online."
overview.collectedData: "Used a dataset of 50,000 online transactions, capturing user demographics, browsing history, and purchase behavior."
overview.conclusions: "Decision Trees outperformed Logistic Regression with an accuracy of 82%. Key factors influencing purchase decisions include product reviews, discount percentages, and cart abandonment rate."
